ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Economic evaluation of chemical plants, safety analysis of chemical plants, how to design a plant, optimizing parameters, what goes into the design of a chemical plant
I learned about the elements that compose process design and about how process design engineers go about designing an innovative system
I developed Econ skills and how to use aspen HYSYS
I developed the ability to evaluate the economic viability of a chemical plant and develop ideal design for a set of goals.
The financial, modeling, and hazard management aspects of chemical engineering

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths
- the professor. He's the best
- interesting material that doesn't feel repetitive from previous courses
- feels like a culmination of my education here without being too difficult
I think the course was strong. I liked the lectures at the beginning to help with the project later. And I felt like there was enough time allocated to the capstone project
I think that this course could be taught in the fall and a more hands-on capstone course could be taught in the spring.

The course is very well taught and provides exposure to industry, which is somewhat lacking in previous classes. A weakness is that there is very little time to complete the project. Rather, introducing and starting the project earlier could be helpful.

I think it benefited from having an industrial perspective, which is what was surprisingly missing from the majority of the ChemE education. The downside to that is that it felt like everything was sandwiched into one semester, so it was hard to relate the importance of most of what was taught to the rest of the education we have received.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if it's required. Honestly, as far as ChemE classes go, not too bad

You should take this course just to have Dr. Khalil as a professor. He is incredibly kind and understanding, but also has a lot of valuable industry insight that is somewhat lacking in the ChemE courses. The problem sets and midterms were more than fair. The course material moved very quickly and could be hard to grasp, but the project highlighted the important parts of the material. The project was interesting, and Dr. Khalil gave ample feedback throughout the process. He really wants everyone in the course to enjoy it and do well.
Only if youre interested in process design
I would, but only to other Chemical engineering students.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course. I really enjoyed and greatly appreciated the industry exposure and this class and Professor provided. Design and evaluation skills are developed in this course as well, which are essential.
I think you have to as an ABET ChemE. Without this requirement, I would encourage doing research instead.
